pros: I loved working along side professors. It is a great real world experience.
cons: Sometimes getting students to participate in study sessions was hard. Especially during covid times.

pros:
- Good, low stress job for a student
- Bosses are friendly and helpful, for the most part
cons:
- Change of promotion is very slim
- A few of the bosses talk behind employees backs

pros: Most offices on campus will work with you to work around your class schedule.
cons: Some offices expect a lot from you.

pros: Great place to grow and work
cons: Long commute and limited parking

pros: Down to earth, friendly staff and students. Very welcoming. Hard working students, many first generation.
cons: Pay is low wiring for state and no increases or benefits fir part-time contractors.

pros: Good Student Job for students.
cons: Its not high paying but it's great for students.

job_title: Professor of Marketing in Framingham, MA
pros:
Faculty are dedicated
opportunity to transform lives
pay is OK
encourages scholarship but it is not a publish or perish institution
institution embraces diversity and inclusion & does not tolerate racism
Faculty and administration get along & work together even though we have a union.
cons:
pay is just OK
change on campus is slow which can be frustrating
university is not living up to its potential

pros: Allows students to get good experience
cons: Coworkers not always the most compassionate

pros:
Great work environment
Strong benefits
Most employees have long tenure/low turnover
An entrepreneurial environment for new ideas (as long as they don't cost too much)
cons:
Tight budget
Union leadership is impossible to get in contact with and is unwilling to help on issues - was there for four years without an election for representation
Impossible to move up or get promoted or get merit-based pay increase

pros: The people make it worth it.  State work so it's pretty secure if you're full-time exempt.  Benefits are decent.  Can maintain a positive work life balance.  Pensions are still a possibility.
cons: Relatively small so not much room to move up unless you're really patient.  No raises or cost of living increases in a long time.  Unions are required and don't do much of anything for employees.

pros: I worked at Framingham State University for a little over a year and found my coworkers and supervisors to be supportive people.
cons: There were no downsides for the position I had at Framingham State University. I worked in a part-time position with the University and I was able to make my own schedule.

pros: Pay is good compared to other universities, and professors are friendly providing a welcoming collegial atmosphere.
cons: FSU is a state school and subject to budget cuts and regulations. No healthcare for adjunct teachers even though they may work 20 hours a week or more! Parking is difficult. Facilities old and in need of updating.

pros: Collaboration between departments.  Ability to create programs and projects and "make them yours".
cons: Current economic conditions has limited growth and expansion of programs and services.

review_title: Great place to learn about working in an office
job_title: Student Office Assistant in Framingham, MA
pros: I was able to balance my schoolwork with my work study and learn how an office runs. Increasing levels of responsibility the longer I was there.
cons: More opportunities to work longer hours would be nice,  but I honestly had a great experience here!

review_title: Just barely helps you get back
job_title: Security Desk Attendant in Framingham, MA
pros: An opportunity to work a lot of hours, easy to get homework done, easy work
cons: Impossible to get shifts covered, strict policies, affects social life negatively
